flow.context: Karlos Salinas is VP at Oranj Palm Vacation Homes, the vacation-rental arm of Palm Springs Rental Agency — a legacy Coachella Valley operator since 1972 managing 100-300 properties across Palm Springs to La Quinta. He owns all day-to-day management operations and came up through communications and marketing (CSU San Bernardino). They run Track PMS, have a dedicated QA department and maintenance crew, and already use OpenAI on their site for guest review summarization — so they're tech-forward, but no inspection platform like Breezeway has been detected. Their biggest local competitor, ACME House Company, already runs Breezeway and Matterport. Strongest Sam connection: both SoCal natives — Sam grew up in the LA area, Karlos is in the desert — and Sam works with similar PM operators in comparable markets.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Karlos — I work with a few other vacation rental operators out in the Coachella Valley. I'm actually from LA originally so I know the area pretty well. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet-up energy. Sound like a peer, not a pitch. Pause after 'tossed around' and let him respond. Do NOT fill the silence.

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — PIVOT TO PAIN
heard_name_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with a few other property managers running a pretty similar setup to you guys. Hundred-plus homes, in-house QA, the whole deal. And what keeps coming up is that even with a dedicated quality team, stuff slips through the cracks during turnovers. Someone's reviewing two hundred photos across fifteen checkouts on a Friday before Coachella weekend, and a cracked tile or a missing patio cushion just… doesn't get caught. Then it's a guest complaint, an owner on the phone, maybe a review hit. The QA folks aren't lazy — they're just looking at too many photos across too many homes.
heard_name_no.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the pain land. Do not rush into the solution. Wait for Karlos to react — even if it's just a 'yeah' or silence. The Coachella weekend detail makes it visceral for a desert operator. If he stays quiet for 2-3 seconds, continue to the solution.

branches.label: Yeah, that's real / I hear you / silence then engagement
We're pretty set on our process
We don't have budget for that

pain_landed_solution.label: SOLUTION DROP + CTA
pain_landed_solution.say: Yeah — so we built something that plugs right into Track, which I know you guys are already on, and it automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues in the turnover photos your team's already taking. No workflow change at all. Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_landed_solution.note: One sentence of solution, one sentence of CTA. Don't oversell. If he says yes, STOP PITCHING and move to discovery.

branches.label: Yeah, that's interesting / tell me more
What does that actually look like?
We already have something for that

heard_name_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you on the inspection side. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let them talk. Whatever they share, bridge to discovery. If it's vague, pivot to the short pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Don't apologize. Be easy about it. Suggest specific days to lock in a window.

reschedule_callback.label: LOCK IN CALLBACK
reschedule_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try you Thursday. Morning or afternoon work better for you?
reschedule_callback.note: Get a time window. This is a real commitment — write it down. Calendar it immediately.

callback_confirmed.label: CALLBACK CONFIRMED
callback_confirmed.say: Got it — I'll ring you then. Appreciate it, Karlos.
callback_confirmed.note: Short and clean. Don't add anything. Calendar it now. When you call back Thursday, open with 'Hey Karlos, it's Sam Parks — you told me to try you back today.'

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: Honesty disarms. If he says yes, go to the short pain trigger. Keep it tight — you promised 30 seconds.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — LAST SHOT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what RapidEye does and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This is your last card. Split the rejection. If it's timing, salvage a callback. If it's disinterest, exit clean. If they ask what RapidEye does — they just opened the door.

pain_trigger_short.label: PAIN TRIGGER — SHORT VERSION
pain_trigger_short.say: Yeah so — short version. I work with a few vacation rental operators running a similar setup to you guys. Hundred-plus homes, turnovers stacking up, QA team doing their best but stuff still slips through the photos. We built something that catches damage and missing items automatically in the turnover photos you're already taking — plugs right into Track. Would you be open to taking a look?
pain_trigger_short.note: Compressed version — you promised 30 seconds. Hit the pain, one line of solution, CTA. Pause after 'taking a look.'

branches.label: We already have a process for that

warm_reaction.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_reaction.say: Yeah — so before I talk your ear off, can I ask — what does your QA process actually look like right now on a turnover day? Are your inspectors going through photos manually or is it more of a walkthrough-based thing?
warm_reaction.note: STOP SELLING. They're interested — now ask questions. They have a QA department. Figure out how it actually works. Listen more than you talk.

branches.label: We use a specific tool / system

discovery_questions.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_questions.say: That makes sense. And when something does get missed — like a guest checks in and flags damage that should've been caught — how does that typically play out? Does that land on your desk, or does Lucia's ops team handle that?
discovery_questions.note: Name-drop Lucia Macklis (Operations Manager) to show you've done homework. Ask about downstream impact. You want Karlos to feel the cost of the current gap — not just describe the process.

branches.label: It's a real headache / shares frustration
We handle it but it's manageable
That's more Lucia's / ops team's area

discovery_current_tool.label: DISCOVERY — THEY HAVE A TOOL
discovery_current_tool.say: Oh interesting — is that something that's actually catching issues before guests check in, or is it more of a documentation thing after the fact?
discovery_current_tool.note: If it's Track checklists or basic photo logs, that's not the same as AI analysis. Differentiate without trashing their tool. If they say Breezeway, acknowledge it and position RapidEye as the analysis layer on top.

branches.label: We use Breezeway or similar ops tool

discovery_manual.label: DISCOVERY — MANUAL PROCESS
discovery_manual.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I hear from most operators your size. The photos get taken, they go into Track, but nobody's really analyzing every single one across a hundred-plus homes. Especially heading into festival season when you've got back-to-back turnovers. How many turnovers are you guys running on a peak weekend?
discovery_manual.note: Get them quantifying the problem. Peak Coachella Valley = Coachella fest, Stagecoach, winter snowbird season. The volume makes manual review physically impossible.

discovery_volume.label: DISCOVERY — TURNOVER VOLUME + IMPACT
discovery_volume.say: And out of curiosity — when those turnovers are stacking up, is your QA team physically walking each property, or are they mostly working off photos that the cleaners send in?
discovery_volume.note: This question tells you their exact workflow and where RapidEye fits. If QA is photo-based, RapidEye is a direct upgrade. If walkthrough-based, RapidEye could reduce the need for physical visits.

discovery_breezeway_angle.label: DISCOVERY — BREEZEWAY USER
discovery_breezeway_angle.say: Nice — Breezeway's great for the task management side. The thing we keep hearing though is the photos still go into Breezeway and nobody's really looking at all of them with enough detail to catch everything. We actually sit on top of Breezeway and automatically analyze every photo that gets uploaded. Does your team feel like they're actually catching everything in those photos, or does stuff still slip through?
discovery_breezeway_angle.note: Don't trash Breezeway. Position RapidEye as the AI analysis layer on top. If they're happy with Breezeway, this is the only differentiator that matters.

solution_drop.label: SOLUTION — CLEAR EXPLANATION
solution_drop.say: Yeah — so what we built is basically an AI layer that sits on top of Track and analyzes every turnover photo your team's already uploading. It flags damage, missing items, staging issues — automatically. Your QA team doesn't change anything they're doing. They just get a report that tells them exactly what needs attention before the next guest walks in.
solution_drop.note: Clear, one-shot explanation. Don't go deeper unless asked. Pause and let him react. Then move to CTA.

branches.label: That sounds useful / how does it work?
I'd need to loop in Thomas / others

solution_drop_walkthrough.label: SOLUTION — WALKTHROUGH ANGLE
solution_drop_walkthrough.say: Got it — so we actually have two modes. One analyzes the photos your cleaners or inspectors are already taking. The other lets someone do a quick video walkthrough on their phone — just walk the property for sixty seconds — and our AI flags everything that's changed, missing, or damaged. Either way, it means your QA team catches more without spending more time in the field.
solution_drop_walkthrough.note: The video walkthrough angle is relevant if they do physical inspections. It positions RapidEye as a way to reduce the need for in-person QA visits. Pause, then CTA.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in my team

cta_meeting.label: CTA — BOOK THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to a twenty-minute look next week? I can walk you through exactly how it works with Track and show you what it catches on real turnover photos. I've got next Tuesday or Wednesday open — what works better for you?
cta_meeting.note: Specific days. Don't say 'sometime.' Twenty minutes is low commitment. If he wants ops team involved, that's a great sign.

branches.label: Can you loop in my ops team too?

cta_meeting_price.label: PRICE QUESTION — REDIRECT
cta_meeting_price.say: Totally fair question. It depends on unit count and how you're set up — but honestly it'd be way easier to show you what it does and talk pricing in context rather than throw a number at you on a cold call. Could we do twenty minutes next week? I'll come with specifics for your setup.
cta_meeting_price.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Redirect to meeting where you can anchor value first.

cta_meeting_ballpark.label: BALLPARK REDIRECT
cta_meeting_ballpark.say: I hear you — for an operator your size, the companies I work with are typically spending less per property than what a single missed damage claim costs them. But I really don't want to throw out a number without showing you what it actually does — that wouldn't be fair to you. Twenty minutes, I'll make it worth your time. How's next week look?
cta_meeting_ballpark.note: Value anchor without a dollar amount. One more push for the meeting. If they push again, concede and offer to include pricing context in an email.

book_meeting.label: BOOK IT — LOCK THE TIME
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday pulled up — how's two o'clock Pacific? I'll send you a calendar invite right now so it doesn't get lost.
book_meeting.note: Specific time. Send the invite to Karlos@oranjpalm.com while still on the phone. Confirm the email address verbally.

book_meeting_with_ops.label: BOOK WITH OPS TEAM
book_meeting_with_ops.say: Absolutely — that'd actually be ideal. Would Lucia on the ops side be the right person to have on? I can send the invite to both of you. How's next Tuesday or Wednesday?
book_meeting_with_ops.note: Name-dropping Lucia Macklis shows research and gets a reaction. If he confirms, get her email too. Multiple stakeholders = higher buying intent.

branches.label: Yeah, include Lucia / the ops team
Let me check with them and get back to you

meeting_adjust_time.label: ADJUST TIME
meeting_adjust_time.say: No problem — what day and time work best on your end?
meeting_adjust_time.note: Let them pick. Whatever they say, confirm and send the invite immediately.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — CLOSE CLEAN
meeting_booked.say: Done — you'll see that invite in a second. Really appreciate you taking my call, Karlos. I'll come prepared with stuff specific to your setup. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Do not add features, benefits, or anything else. Send the invite within 60 seconds. Send a short confirmation email within 5 minutes with one line of value and nothing else.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED — AGREE FIRST
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out, right?
objection_not_interested.note: Miyagi step 1: Agree. Disarm. Do NOT push back. Pause after 'right?' — most people soften when you don't fight them.

not_interested_split.label: SPLIT THE OBJECTION
not_interested_split.say: Totally fair. And just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it more that inspections just aren't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it that you hate cold calls as much as I hate making them?
not_interested_split.note: Miyagi step 2: Split with humor on the cold call option. If it's timing, you have an opening. If it's 'not a problem,' most operators can't say QA is fully solved with a straight face.

branches.label: It's the cold call / bad timing thing
Just not focused on this right now

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET — AGREE FIRST
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool than to buy something new, right?
objection_no_budget.note: Miyagi step 1: Agree and validate. Don't pitch cost savings yet.

branches.label: Yeah exactly / it's tough right now

no_budget_split.label: SPLIT THE BUDGET OBJECTION
no_budget_split.say: Yeah — and just so I know, is it that the budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that trying to buy anything new puts you through the ringer internally?
no_budget_split.note: Miyagi step 2: If budget is locked, sell the test drive for next cycle. If it's approval chain (likely Thomas needs to sign off), offer to help build the case.

branches.label: Approval process is tough / Thomas would need to sign off

objection_have_process.label: HAVE A PROCESS — AGREE FIRST
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a hundred-plus properties and a dedicated QA team, you'd have to have something in place. You'd be in trouble if you didn't, right?
objection_have_process.note: Miyagi step 1: Agree and compliment. Don't trash their process. Having a QA focus is actually a buying signal — it means they care about quality.

have_process_split.label: SPLIT THE PROCESS OBJECTION
have_process_split.say: And just out of curiosity — is it that your current process catches everything and you're fully happy with it, or is it more that switching or adding anything right now would just be a headache?
have_process_split.note: Miyagi step 2: Very few operators will say with a straight face that their process catches everything. If it's switching hassle, the 'no workflow change' angle is your strongest card.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have

test_drive_pitch.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive_pitch.say: Yeah — and look, you're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But the people who end up moving on stuff like this are usually the ones who already looked at it before they needed it. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other operators in the desert are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would twenty minutes be worth it?
test_drive_pitch.note: Low pressure. 'Other operators in the desert' = social proof without naming names (ACME, Poppy, etc.). The meeting has value even if he never buys.

branches.label: Yeah, I'd be open to that

test_drive_pitch_with_referral.label: TEST DRIVE + LOOP IN DECISION MAKER
test_drive_pitch_with_referral.say: That's super common actually. What if we did this — I walk you through it in twenty minutes, and if it's worth a conversation with Thomas, you'd already have all the context to make the case. No pressure either way. Would that make sense?
test_drive_pitch_with_referral.note: Thomas Salinas is President and controls budget/tech decisions. Positioning the meeting as arming Karlos to make the internal case is a power move — it respects his org structure.

branches.label: Let me talk to Thomas first
Send me something I can forward

test_drive_pitch_compare.label: TEST DRIVE — BENCHMARK ANGLE
test_drive_pitch_compare.say: Love that — honestly, companies that already care about QA are the ones that get the most out of what we do. Would it be worth twenty minutes just to see how it stacks up against what you're doing now? If your process is better, I'll be the first to say keep it.
test_drive_pitch_compare.note: Frame the meeting as a benchmark, not a replacement pitch. 'I'll tell you to keep it' removes perceived sales pressure.

test_drive_no_workflow_change.label: TEST DRIVE — NO CHANGE ANGLE
test_drive_no_workflow_change.say: Totally hear you — and that's actually the whole point of what we built. It sits on top of Track, your team doesn't change anything they're doing, and it just adds a layer of automated analysis to the photos they're already uploading. There's genuinely nothing to switch. Could I show you in twenty minutes how it works?
test_drive_no_workflow_change.note: This is your strongest card for the 'switching is a hassle' objection. They already use Track. RapidEye plugs in. Zero disruption. Let the simplicity sell.

referral_to_ops.label: REFERRAL — DOWN TO OPS
referral_to_ops.say: Totally makes sense — would Lucia on the ops side be the right person to talk to about this? Or is there someone else who owns the inspection workflow day to day?
referral_to_ops.note: Karlos is delegating down. That's fine — Lucia Macklis (Operations Manager, 760-406-8606) is actually the ideal daily-pain user. Get a warm intro or at minimum permission to use Karlos's name.

referral_up.label: REFERRAL — UP TO THOMAS
referral_up.say: Yeah — would it make sense for me to reach out to Thomas directly? Or would it land better coming from you with some context? Happy to do it either way.
referral_up.note: Thomas Salinas is President and likely controls tech budget. Let Karlos decide the path — either way works. If direct, use thomas@oranjpalm.com.

branches.label: Let me bring it to him first
Let's do the meeting first then loop him in

referral_get_contact.label: GET THE CONTACT
referral_get_contact.say: Awesome — if I can get their best number or email, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't look like spam. What's the best way to reach them?
referral_get_contact.note: You likely already have the info (Lucia: 760-406-8606 / Lucia@oranjpalm.com — Thomas: thomas@oranjpalm.com — Alexander: 760-320-4952) but let Karlos give it. His handoff validates the contact and warms the outreach.

branches.label: I'll have them reach out to you / forward your info

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED
referral_confirmed.say: Perfect — I really appreciate that, Karlos. I'll reach out to them and mention you pointed me their way. Thanks for taking my call.
referral_confirmed.note: Use Karlos's name as social proof when contacting the referral: 'Karlos mentioned you'd be the right person to talk to about this.' Contact the referral within the hour while it's fresh.

referral_internal_pass.label: INTERNAL PASS — MAKE IT EASY
referral_internal_pass.say: Totally — and would it help if I shot you a quick email you could forward? That way you don't have to explain the whole thing — just a two-liner they can look at.
referral_internal_pass.note: Make it effortless for Karlos. Send a short, forwardable email to Karlos@oranjpalm.com within 10 minutes. Two sentences of value, one calendar link, no attachments.

referral_email_confirmed.label: FORWARDABLE EMAIL CONFIRMED
referral_email_confirmed.say: Done — I'll send that in the next five minutes. Really appreciate your time, Karlos.
referral_email_confirmed.note: Send immediately. Max 3 sentences. Subject line should include Karlos's name: 'Following up on my call with Karlos.' Include calendar link. Follow up in 3 days if no response.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL — ACCEPT + EXTRACT INTEL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch in your inbox — would it be more helpful to see how it works with Track specifically, or more the ROI side, like what it actually catches that gets missed?
send_email.note: Accept the email request gracefully. Their answer tells you what matters to them: technical integration vs. business case. Send to Karlos@oranjpalm.com.

branches.label: The Track integration / how it works

send_email_close.label: CLOSE — SET FOLLOW-UP
send_email_close.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. And just so it doesn't get buried — would it be cool if I followed up Thursday to make sure it landed?
send_email_close.note: Lock in a follow-up touchpoint. Send the email within 30 minutes, tailored to their answer. Include a specific time suggestion for a call. Calendar a Thursday follow-up regardless of what they say.

send_email_confirmed.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
send_email_confirmed.say: Perfect. Appreciate your time, Karlos — talk soon.
send_email_confirmed.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Tailor to what they asked for. Include a P.S. referencing something from this conversation so it doesn't feel templated. Follow up Thursday at the same time you reached him today.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand, Karlos. If anything ever comes up on the inspection side, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Send a short, non-pushy email to Karlos@oranjpalm.com: your name, one sentence about RapidEye, your contact info. No pitch. Flag to retry in 3-6 months or try a different contact (Lucia, Thomas, Alexander).
